Input.threadtitle: Vectorization of 'delta' in the Vectorization Lecture
Input.posts:
In Week 2 lecture of 'Vectorization', the second example is to vectorize the linear regression algorithm with more than 2 features (n>2). In the lecture the parameter theta is expressed using vector form as: theta := theta - alpha * delta where delta = 1/m* ( sum((h(x(i))-y(i))*x(i)) ) Here, theta is (n+1)*1 vector, alpha is a constant, delta is also a (n+1) vector. I found that delta can also be vectorized as delta = 1/m * [x' * (h(x)-y)] where x is a m*(n+1) matrix, each row is a set of observation, containing (n+1) features. h(x)-y is a m*1 vector, therefore the product of [x' * (h(x)-y)] gives a (n+1)*1 vector, which is delta. Any thoughts?

Input.threadtitle: Two features and a cubic regression model
Input.posts:
In polynomial regression, as in 'Features and Polynomial Regression', we had one feature, namely the size of the house and we want to predict its price. A cubic model was getting fitted into data most accurately. But we had three variables in cubic hypothesis function namely x1, x2, x3 (x0 = 1), so what we did is we simply plugged in size into all x1, x2, x3. Now suppose if we had two features, say size and #bedrooms and we want to use cubic model, what should be the value of x1, x2, x3?
Upvotes:
0
Suppose size is denoted by $$x$$ and #bedrooms by $$z$$. Your hypothesis could be like: $$h_\mathbf{\theta}(x,z)= \mathbf{\theta}_1x+\mathbf{\theta}_2x^{2} +\mathbf{\theta}_3x^{3} + \mathbf{\theta}_3z^{3}$$ Replace higher powers with $$x_1, x_2, x_3 $$ and so on. But you cannot have power of $$\mathbf{\theta}$$
Upvotes:
0
A cubic model means that you use features that are combinations (i.e. multiplication) of three of the original features. If you have two original features, say size of house (x1) and # of bedrooms (x2), then a cubic model with complete interactions would have all combinations of these two original features up to the third degree: $$h = \theta_0 x_0 + \theta_1 x_1 + \theta_2 x_2 + \theta_3 x_1 x_2 + \theta_4 x_1^2 x_2 + \theta_5 x_1 x_2^2 + \theta_6 x_1^3 + \theta_7 x_2^3 + \theta_8 x_1^2 + \theta_9 x_2^2$$ Now, it depends on the problem whether to use all these features make sense or not. You could use only size of house to the cube and the original # of bedrooms. That would make for a simpler cubic model: $$h = \theta_0 x_0 + \theta_1 x_1^3 + \theta_2 x_2$$ There is no rule about which features to add. You choose the ones that make sense to your problem. Hope I did not make it sound more confusing that it actually is.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Neelmani, You can invent as many additional features as you think might be useful. Gradient Descent will adjust their theta values as necessary if the additional factors do not contribute to the solution. Here's an experiment: Create a linear set of features X = [1; 2; 3; 4 ;5] and set y = 2*X. Create extra x features for x^2 and x^3. Remember to add the bias value to X. Run gradient descent, and study the resulting theta values. Note that (without normalization) I had to use a very small value for alpha, and a very large number of iterations. It is useful to use this sequence to display the 'known good' values vs. the result of gradient descent. plot(X(:,2),y,'o') % displays the known data as circles hold % preserves the figure plot(X*theta) % overlays a curve of the predicted data

In polynomial regression, as in 'Features and Polynomial Regression', we had one feature, namely the size of the house and we want to predict its price. A cubic model was getting fitted into data most accurately. But we had three variables in cubic hypothesis function namely x1, x2, x3 (x0 = 1), so what we did is we simply plugged in size into all x1, x2, x3. Now suppose if we had two features, say size and #bedrooms and we want to use cubic model, what should be the value of x1, x2, x3?
Upvotes:
0
Suppose size is denoted by $$x$$ and #bedrooms by $$z$$. Your hypothesis could be like: $$h_\mathbf{\theta}(x,z)= \mathbf{\theta}_1x+\mathbf{\theta}_2x^{2} +\mathbf{\theta}_3x^{3} + \mathbf{\theta}_3z^{3}$$ Replace higher powers with $$x_1, x_2, x_3 $$ and so on. But you cannot have power of $$\mathbf{\theta}$$
Upvotes:
0
A cubic model means that you use features that are combinations (i.e. multiplication) of three of the original features. If you have two original features, say size of house (x1) and # of bedrooms (x2), then a cubic model with complete interactions would have all combinations of these two original features up to the third degree: $$h = \theta_0 x_0 + \theta_1 x_1 + \theta_2 x_2 + \theta_3 x_1 x_2 + \theta_4 x_1^2 x_2 + \theta_5 x_1 x_2^2 + \theta_6 x_1^3 + \theta_7 x_2^3 + \theta_8 x_1^2 + \theta_9 x_2^2$$ Now, it depends on the problem whether to use all these features make sense or not. You could use only size of house to the cube and the original # of bedrooms. That would make for a simpler cubic model: $$h = \theta_0 x_0 + \theta_1 x_1^3 + \theta_2 x_2$$ There is no rule about which features to add. You choose the ones that make sense to your problem. Hope I did not make it sound more confusing that it actually is.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Neelmani, You can invent as many additional features as you think might be useful. Gradient Descent will adjust their theta values as necessary if the additional factors do not contribute to the solution. Here's an experiment: Create a linear set of features X = [1; 2; 3; 4 ;5] and set y = 2*X. Create extra x features for x^2 and x^3. Remember to add the bias value to X. Run gradient descent, and study the resulting theta values. Note that (without normalization) I had to use a very small value for alpha, and a very large number of iterations. It is useful to use this sequence to display the 'known good' values vs. the result of gradient descent. plot(X(:,2),y,'o') % displays the known data as circles hold % preserves the figure plot(X*theta) % overlays a curve of the predicted data

When n = 2 the cost function $$J({ \theta }_{ 0 },{ \theta }_{ 1 })\quad$$, will be a convex function and thus will only have 1 global minimum (as stated in previous lecture) . However, in the case when n >2 the cost function is no longer a convex function and could have multiple local minima. How can we ennsure that the gradient descent algorithm converges to the global minimum and not any one of these local minima?
Upvotes:

Javan, I'm going to be writing some things here, partially for my own development. I may very well be wrong. But here goes nothing. First of all, I do remember the Prof. mentioning that our cost function with two parameters will be convex, but I don't seem to remember him saying that more parameters will make it not convex. Try to look at the gradient descent algorithm and figure out how it works. We have: theta = theta - (alpha) (1 / m) (partial derivative (in respect to the current theta) of cost function); update simultaneously. Now, I hadn't done partial derivatives before when I saw this, so I grabbed a handy calculus textbook and took a look at how they work. Basically, you take partial derivatives when you have multiple variables. To take the derivative of x in respect to a function that has x, y, and z, you treat all other variables as constants - aka, y and z are treated as constants when using your 'derivative rules.' To explain this in a more conceptual way, imagine what you have when you have a function with multiple variables. The graph of this function has multiple dimensions! So how can you find the slope of the line tangent to a certain point, if you have multiple dimensions. With two variables, you'd have to be finding a tangent plane, with three, presumably a tangent cube, and so on. By setting all other variables constant, you are putting you graph into 2 dimensions again, so that you CAN infact find a single line that is tangent to the point. You can also think of it as a science experiment - you have to hold all of the other variables 'constant' to see how one variable affects the end result of your experiment. So, what we end up taking is the derivative of a curve that represents how 'good' the value of a certain theta is. For each of the thetas, the curve should be convex, so we end up being fine. Now, that probably wasn't a great explanation, but I hope it got something across. For the next lectures, the classification lectures, we will indeed find that our cost function will result in a non-convex shape, so we'll need to modify it. But everything should work fine for simple linear regression.
